column17: Add a complete list of profiles defined as part of DAF-Research, preferably near the top of the implementation guide page. This list should include profiles that are derived form DAF-Core (e.g. Condition) or profiles based on FHIR spec resources (e.g. DAF-Task). Currently, The reader must go through all sections of guide to discover research profiles.  It appears that there are 4 profiles derived form DAF-Core and 3 profiles based on FHIR spec resources.
column18: Add complete profile list for DAF-Research.

column17: Change profile Id nameing pattern for DAF-Research profiles. All profiles defined by DAF-Core have Ids with prefix "daf-core", e.g. "daf-core-conditin".  Modify DAF-Research profile Ids so that all have prefix "daf-research".  Currently, profile "daf-condition" is derived from "daf-core-condition" and "daf-task" is derived from FHIR base resource "Task".
column18: Change profile Ids to have prefix "daf-research"

column17:
The content includes various resources that are currently not in DAF-Core.  It sounds though that DAF-Research is meant to be built on DAF-Core.  However, when that happens, DAF-Core would contain more than needed for CCDS in 2015 Cert Edition.  So either the scope of DAF-Research needs to be clarified that it pulls from multiple sources, or if indeed DAF-Core is meant to be the only source, then DAF-Core needs to be split into DAF-Core and DAF-CCDS.
See comment in other ballot that given DAF-Core's scope, it really should be called DAF-CCDS.
Another example would be Device where CCDS would be more restrictive (implementable devices) than DAF-Research would likely be interested in, further questioning the relationship and naming between these IGs.
column18: Review DAF Core to DAF research

column17: It is unclear how DAF-Research can point to FHIR resources without specific profiles.  Is this because of the phase of development (i.e., it's TBD, which then should be clarified), or truly that no profile is expected.  If the latter, unclear how to set expectations on vocabulary bindings.  Perhaps less so on ValueSet, but more so for Specimen
column18: Review DAF research and how can point to FHIR resources without specific profiles

column15: Data Sources are advised to implement security requirements according to their existing protocols for data extraction purposes. However Data Sources implementing DAF-Core IG can reuse their security protocols for data extraction purposes as applicable.
column16:
Data Sources SHALL conform with DAF Core Security (http://hl7.org/FHIR/us/daf/2016Sep/daf-security.html).

Data sources SHOULD honor patients' data disclosure policies as documented by the FHIR Consent Resources
column17: Because this is a FHIR ballot, I assume that data sources are FHIR APIs.  Hence DAF Core Security must apply without exception. Also, patient consent is a major consideration in research.
column18: DAF Core Security must apply without exception and patient consent is a major consideration in research

column15: Data Marts are advised to implement security requirements according to their existing protocols for data translation and loading purposes. However Data Marts implementing DAF-Core IG can reuse their security protocols for data translation and loading purposes as applicable.
column16:
Data Marts are advised to implement security requirements according to their existing protocols for data translation and loading purposes. However Data Marts implementing DAF-Core IG can reuse their security protocols for data translation and loading purposes as applicable.

Datamarts SHOULD apply de-identification to patient identifiable data, in accordance with HHS's "Guidance Regarding Methods for De-identification of Protected Health Information in Accordance with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Privacy Rule", ISO/TS 25237: Health Informatics - Pseudonymization, and available industry best practices such as the IHE De-identification Handbook: (http://www.ihe.net/uploadedFiles/Documents/ITI/IHE_ITI_Handbook_De-Identification_Rev1.1_2014-06-06.pdf)

Datamarts SHOULD honor patients' data disclosure policies as documented by the FHIR Consent Resources
column17: De-identification for patient privacy are a major consideration in research.  Also, patient consent is a major consideration in research.
column18: De-identification for patient privacy and patient consent is a major consideration in research.

column15: Research Query Requester are advised to implement security requirements according to their existing protocols for executing research queries. However Research Query Requesters implementing DAF-Core IG can reuse their security protocols for query execution purposes as applicable.
column16:
Research Query Requesters are advised to implement security requirements according to their existing protocols for executing research queries. However Research Query Requesters implementing DAF-Core IG SHALL conform with DAF Core Security (http://hl7.org/FHIR/us/daf/2016Sep/daf-security.html).

Research Query Requestors SHOULD honor patients' data disclosure policies as documented by the FHIR Consent Resources
column17: Mandate uniform security conformance for all DAF Core Security.  Also, patient consent is a major consideration in research.
column18: Mandate uniform security conformance for all DAF Core Security.  Also, patient consent is a major consideration in research.

column15: Research Query Responder are advised to implement security requirements according to their existing protocols for query execution and returning results. However Research Query Responders implementing DAF-Core IG can reuse their security protocols for data translation and loading purposes as applicable.
column16:
Research Query Responders SHALL conform with DAF Core Security (http://hl7.org/FHIR/us/daf/2016Sep/daf-security.html).

Research Query Responders SHOULD honor patients' data disclosure policies as documented by the FHIR Consent Resources
column17: Because this is a FHIR ballot, I assume that query responders are FHIR APIs.  Hence DAF Core Security must apply without exception. Also, patient consent is a major consideration in research.
column18: DAF Core Security must apply without exception. Patient consent is a major consideration in research.

column15: DAF-Research IG on the other hand will focus on enabling researchers to access data from multiple organizations in the context of Learning Health System (LHS). The capabilities created as part of DAF-Research are intended to be leveraged to build our nation’s data infrastructure for a Learning Health System. DAF-Research IG will leverage work that has been completed and tested as part of the DAF-Core IG

column15: However data extraction programs have to be aware that vendors may be supporting just DAF-Core or a subset of DAF-Core for their initial implementation and hence may not have all the PCORnet CDM data elements available.
column16: Implementers should prepare for significant heterogeneity in source data and budget time and resources accordingly. At this time conformance to any data standards in EHRs is low, which is why the mapping task is challenging. Implementers should evaluate extraction methods and assume significant costs for mapping and transformation in addition to extraction. Most vendors for data warehousing software do not support DAF-Core.
column17: Potentially put in cost estimates. Some of these projects cost hundreds of thousands of dollars and take up to a year to complete. For a poor-man's version we tell collaborators $50,000 per source that needs to be harmonized and Quality Controlled. Also some guidance on retrospective vs. prospective data. (Retrospective data is used/needed for research, but the older data is the worse the quality, so even if new data conforms, old data might not).
column18: Implementation costs unclear

column15:
Implementing C1 capability involves four steps.

Instantiation of a Task for Extraction at the Data Source
Execution of the Task to extract data from the Data Source
Instantiation of a Task for Loading of data at the Data Mart
Execution of the Task to load data into the Data Mart

column15: A Bundle returned from Step 2 will conform to FHIR and DAF-Core or other specific IG requirements. This Bundle may have to go through additional transformations, mappings and other processing before it is loaded into a destination Data Mart. One of these processing steps is “De-Identifying the data”.
column16: A Bundle returned from Step 2 will conform to FHIR and DAF-Core or other specific IG requirements. This Bundle may have to go through additional transformations, mappings and other processing before it is loaded into a destination Data Mart.  These include  “De-Identifying the data” discussed next as well as other steps beyond the scope of this IG, such as psudonymization and patient matching following incremental updates.
column17: These transformations are essential to the usability and longitudinal integrity of research data and generally consider within the responsibilities of the Data Source.  However, no standard methods or policy guidance are yet available and are outside the current scope of the IG.
column18: Transformations from Bundle 2 are essential to the usability and longitudinal integrity of research data and generally consider within the responsibilities of the Data Source.  However, no standard methods or policy guidance are yet available and are outside the current scope of the IG.

column4: C3: Step 2: Submitting the query to multiple Data Marts
column15: Task.owner - Should be populated with the organization that owns the query
column17: If the query is being assigned to a QueryResponder, then it might be more appropriate for the Task.owner be assigned to a Device rather than an Organization. The Device would represent a software device which is the QueryResponder. This allows for a more targeted assignment of the Research Query Task to a specific QueryResponder.
column18: If the query is being assigned to a QueryResponder, then it might be more appropriate for the Task.owner be assigned to a Device rather than an Organization. The Device would represent a software device which is the QueryResponder. This allows for a more targeted assignment of the Research Query Task to a specific QueryResponder.

column4: Section: C4: Step 2: Executing the query and returning the query results
column15: The query would then be executed and the results would be created using the DAF-QueryResults Observation profile.
column17: Using the DAF-QueryResults Observation profile works well for a single result which equates to a single measurement, but the IG need to clarify how to use this mechanism for returning multiple stratified results using the DAF-QueryResults Observation profile.
column18: Using the DAF-QueryResults Observation profile works well for a single result which equates to a single measurement, but the IG need to clarify how to use this mechanism for returning multiple stratified results using the DAF-QueryResults Observation profile.

column15: This can be achieved using a FHIR API using the POST operation or using a graphical user interface which allows an end user to create the Task instance
column17: Data extraction from source and population into data mart can be completely automated process. In this case task population can be done by scheduler directly instead of graphical user interface/ FHIR post API.
column18: Creation of task resource by scheduler should be  allowed.

column15: Set Task.output.type - Reference. (This is the bundle that contains the data for a desired number of patients) Populate Task.output.valueReference (This should point to the Bundle reference created).
column17: Task outcome might contains huge data, storing it in resource might not be possible all the time. Instead of bundle containing data for patient we should populate patient count. This should be optional field while populating task.
column18: Task.Output should be optional and should contain summary of task output.

column17: Data-standardization step should be included in this section. Data coming from source is unstructured and contains lot of null values. This data should be corrected before mapping.
column18: Data-standardization step is required

column17: Population of the Data Mart task should be in sync with data extraction task (e.g. Data Mart population should not begin if data extraction is in progress.) to avoid data integrity errors.
column18: Avoid data integrity errors between data-Source and data-Mart using Task resource status

column15: "Task.input.valueReference - Patient for whom data has to be extracted. (For e.g Patient/134234, This is an identifier/reference that is known to the DataSource implementing the FHIR API)."
column17: Populating the Data Mart is a BULK extraction operation, then there will be no reference to a specific patient. The reference might be to a certain patient COHORT, but not a specific patient. There will be a big performance problem if the extraction is supposed to happen one patient at a time. I don't think this is a feasible approach.
column18: Review Task.input.valueReference

column15: "Add the data for each patient to a Bundle which contains all the data along with the linkages."
column17: How did a task to request information on a single patient change to a bundle containing information on multiple patients?
column18: Review task patient vs bundled patients

column15: "Task.input.valueReference - Patient for whom data has to be extracted. (For e.g Patient/134234, This is an identifier/reference that is known to the DataSource implementing the FHIR API)."
column17: How does the requestor know the specific patient IDs they should be requesting? It seems there is a big hole, namely, the definition of the cohort of interest, and the identification of the patients in that cohort. What if the cohort is "all new patients" or "update all patients"? We don't want to have to pass the IDs of all patients.
column18: Review Task.input.valueReference- missing information

column15: "Guidance on the profiles to be used to map FHIR Resources to PCORnet Common Data Model"
column17: How do we know the use of FHIR as an intermediary will not entail data loss (or compromised semantics)? Until DAF profiles include all the elements in PCOR CDM and a definitive mapping, this specification should not be approved.
column18: Cross review elements in PCOR CDM and definitive mapping to DAF profiles

column15: "Guidance on the profiles to be used to map FHIR Resources to OMOP"

column15: "It is expected that most vendors supporting the ONC 2015 Edition CCDS API’s or the Patient/$everything operation would be returning identifiable patient information as part of the API. Since PCORnet required de-identified data the de-identification has to be performed subsequently. Implementations can choose internally approved mechanisms for de-identifying the data and populating the PCORnet CDM."
column17: When data is exported for research purposes, it must be already de-identified. Data providers don't do bulk export of PHI. The de-identification will be performed by the Data Source.
column18: Review expectations of deidentification of data

column15: "queryApprovals - Have to be populated using profile of Basic Resource. This needs to be experimented before being used."
column17: This is OK for a rough draft, but the security and authorization aspects of the federated query need to be worked out before the specification is approved.
column18: Review security and authorization aspects of the federated query

column15: "Task.input.valueString - Value which contains the actual query composed using SAS/SQL/Json etc."
column17: It appears that the query itself is a native query against the CDM model. In that case, I don't understand the benefit of introducing FHIR into the picture at all. How does packaging the query into a FHIR Task resource make the process better or simpler than it is already using PCORnet? Explain.
column18: Review approach- Native query agaiast CDM model, what is benefit of FHIR task resource

column15: "The query would then be executed and the results would be created using the DAF-QueryResults Observation profile. The data would be represented as follows..."
column17: So, the plan is to stuff the result set from the query into a FHIR Observation resource? That doesn't seem reasonable. An observation represents a single observation or limited set of related observations about a patient. A research query result set is a table of data. I don't see how this is supposed to work, and I'm dubious that it makes any sense at all. Certainly the specification should give concrete examples of the range of queries possible in OMOP or PCORnet and show how the results would be represented as a FHIR Observation.
column18: Review approach- results set from the query into a FHIR observation resource

column17: NIOSH recommends the inclusion of Occupational Data for Health (ODH) in the FHIR standard. Currently, the ODH HL7 CDA template is in ballot reconciliation through the Structured Documents Work Group. NIOSH is intent on incorporating and aligning ODH in all HL7 standards. A Project Scope Statement (PSS) to format ODH in V2 and FHIR standards is with the Executive Board and Technical Steering Committee (TSC) to identify the appropriate sponsor Work Group. Use cases to support ODH can be provided during ballot reconciliation.
column18: Review if adding ODH is necessary
